title: R44718
content: The 21st Century Cures Act (P.L. 114-255) was signed into law on December 13, 2016, by President Barack Obama after passing through the House and Senate with overwhelming support. The law is divided into three sections: Division A—21st Century Cures; Division B—Helping Families in Mental Health Crisis; and Division C—Increasing Choice, Access, and Quality in Health Care for Americans. Division B, focused on mental health, was the result of a multiyear congressional effort dating back to 2013. In the 113th Congress, the Mental Health Crisis Act of 2013 (H.R. 3717) was introduced without a Senate companion. In the 114th Congress, the Helping Families in Mental Health Crisis Act of 2015 (H.R. 2646) was introduced, along with the Mental Health Reform Act of 2015 (S. 1945). The Mental Health Reform Act of 2016 (S. 2680) combines elements of previous bills and represents a compromise between H.R. 2646 and S. 2680. The Mental Health Reform Act of 2016 (S. 2680 RS) combines elements of previous bills from the 114th Congress. It includes provisions from the Helping Families in Mental Health Crisis Act and the Comprehensive Justice and Mental Health Act. This report offers a summary of the Act by title and subtitle, organizing major provisions by topic. Technical edits are made for clarity, with some summaries more detailed than others to highlight important changes. Division B of the Mental Health Reform Act of 2016, titled "Helping Families in Mental Health Crisis Reform Act of 2016," makes changes to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) within the Department of Health and Human Services. The term "substance abuse" is replaced with "substance use disorder" throughout the provisions. Abbreviations used in the report are listed in the Appendix. Subtitle A of the Mental Health Reform Act of 2016 establishes the position of Assistant Secretary for Mental Health and Substance Use (ASMHSU) to replace the SAMHSA Administrator. The ASMHSU is responsible for collaborating with other federal agencies, developing strategic plans, and preparing biennial reports on activities and progress. Subtitle A of the Mental Health Reform Act of 2016 introduces the ASMHSU position to oversee SAMHSA activities. The ASMHSU must prepare biennial reports with specified contents, appoint a Chief Medical Officer, and modify authorities for SAMHSA's centers. Collaboration requirements with NIH institutes are increased. Each center remains permanently authorized. Subtitle A of the Mental Health Reform Act of 2016 establishes permanent statutory authority for SAMHSA's Center for Behavioral Health Statistics and Quality. It also changes membership requirements for SAMHSA's advisory councils, including the addition of the Chief Medical Officer and Directors of relevant NIH institutes as ex officio members. Relevant clinical experience and training are now required for appointed members of advisory councils for specific centers. Subtitle A of the Mental Health Reform Act of 2016 establishes permanent statutory authority for SAMHSA's Center for Behavioral Health Statistics and Quality, with changes in membership requirements for advisory councils. It also requires relevant experience and training for peer review groups reviewing grants related to mental illness treatment. Funds for emergency response grants under the Public Health Service Act shall remain available for an additional fiscal year, with technical edits made to terminology. Subtitle B of the Mental Health Reform Act of 2016 focuses on planning and evaluation requirements for programs related to mental disorders and substance use disorders. It mandates the HHS Secretary to ensure efficient planning and evaluation, develop an evaluation strategy within 180 days, consult with stakeholders, and make recommendations for program improvement to Congress and the HHS Secretary. The PAIMI Act authorizes grants to protect individuals with mental illness in care facilities from abuse and neglect. Annual reports on activities and expenditures are required to be submitted to the HHS Secretary. The Secretary must provide biennial reports to Congress on program goals and outcomes for individuals with disabilities. Subtitle B of the PAIMI Act mandates protection and advocacy systems to publicly release annual reports on spending details, including federal, state, local, and private funding sources. Additionally, the Comptroller General is required to submit a report to congressional committees on programs funded by PAIMI grants within 18 months of enactment, consulting with the HHS Secretary and ASMHSU. Subtitle C (Section 6031) of the PAIMI Act establishes the "Interdepartmental Serious Mental Illness Coordinating Committee" to evaluate federal programs and make recommendations for services for adults with serious mental illness and children with serious emotional disturbances. The committee must produce a report within one year of enactment and again five years later, with the possibility of extension based on the HHS Secretary's recommendation to Congress. Title VII of the PAIMI Act establishes a "National Mental Health Policy Laboratory" within SAMHSA, codifies the National Registry of Evidence-based Programs and Practices, and authorizes appropriations for SAMHSA's Programs of Regional and National Significance. The Act also includes provisions regarding committee membership, meetings, and working groups, with the Federal Advisory Committee Act applying to the committee. Prior to this, SAMHSA's Office of Policy, Planning, and Innovation facilitated the adoption of evidence-based policies to improve behavioral health services outcomes. Title VII of the PAIMI Act establishes a "National Mental Health Policy Laboratory" within SAMHSA, with responsibilities including improving coordination between mental health and physical health care providers. The laboratory consults with various experts and agencies to carry out its duties. New PHSA Section 501A allows the ASMHSU to award grants for evaluating service delivery models and expanding evidence-based programs. $7 million is authorized for each grant program for FY2018-FY2020. Prior to P.L. 114-255, SAMHSA maintained the National Registry of Evidence-based Programs and Practices (NREPP). Title VII (Section 7002) of the PHSA adds a new section codifying the NREPP, requiring the ASMHSU to post information on evidence-based programs and practices on SAMHSA's website. The ASMHSU must review applications before posting programs and practices, establish an application period, prioritize reviews to address information gaps, and provide notice in the Federal Register for soliciting applications meeting priority criteria. Title VII of the PHSA allows the ASMHSU to establish minimum requirements for applications and use a rating system based on evidence strength and research rigor. SAMHSA administers grants under PRNS for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and prevention. Funding for PRNS programs continued through annual appropriations after authorizations expired. Title VIII authorizes appropriations for mental health PRNS, substance abuse treatment PRNS, and substance abuse prevention PRNS. It allocates $395 million annually for mental health PRNS, $334 million annually for substance abuse treatment PRNS, and $211 million annually for substance abuse prevention PRNS for FY2018–FY2022. The focus is on SAMHSA's Community Mental Health Services Block Grant and Substance Abuse Prevention and Treatment Block Grant. Title VIII of the PHSA authorizes appropriations for mental health and substance abuse programs, allocating specific amounts annually for each. It amends provisions related to the distribution of funds for community mental health services for adults with serious mental illness and children with serious emotional disturbance. Title VIII of the PHSA amends criteria for state plans, requiring submission every two years to the HHS Secretary. It adds new requirements for efficiency, effectiveness, and quality of services, including identifying a single State agency. Additionally, it amends provisions related to maintaining spending on community mental health services and allows waivers under certain circumstances. Title VIII of the PHSA requires states to expend a minimum percentage of block grant funds on evidence-based programs for early serious mental illness. It also authorizes annual appropriations of $533 million for FY2018–FY2022 to implement the MHBG. States can request waivers for maintaining spending levels and negotiate agreements with the HHS Secretary to avoid reductions in their MHBG allotment. Title VIII of the PHSA amends criteria for state plans to distribute SABG funds for substance use disorder services. It requires identifying a single State agency, includes needs assessment, and repeals previous requirements. Title VIII (Section 8002) of the PHSA amends requirements for states receiving SABG funds for substance use disorder services. It allows waivers for maintaining spending levels, offers negotiated agreements for non-compliance, and updates continuing education requirements for ongoing professional development. Title VIII (Section 8002) of the PHSA makes technical edits and authorizes $1.9 billion annually for FY2018–FY2022 for the SABG. It also allows flexibility in meeting deadlines during public health emergencies for various grants related to mental health services. The PHSA allows joint applications for MHBG and SABG through the ASMHSU. A study on block grant formulas considers population, service costs, and resources. Section 8004 mandates a study on fund distribution within two years. PHSA Section 506 authorizes the Treatment Systems for Homeless program under SAMHSA. Subtitle A (Section 9001) of the PHSA makes technical edits to the Treatment Systems for Homeless program, authorizing $41 million annually for FY2018-FY2022. PHSA Section 520G authorizes the Criminal and Juvenile Justice Programs, providing grants for jail diversion programs. Subtitle A (Section 9002) of the PHSA amends Section 520G to prioritize entities supporting jail diversion services for veterans, allowing funds for programs to divert individuals before booking or arrest. It authorizes $4 million annually for FY2018-FY2022 and makes technical edits. Section 520K authorizes a SAMHSA-administered program for integrated mental health and primary care services. Subtitle A (Section 9003) establishes a program for Integration Incentive Grants and Cooperative Agreements, authorizing grants for state agencies collaborating with community programs to provide mental health and primary care services to adults, children, and adolescents with co-occurring chronic diseases. The PHSA Title V, Part C program authorizes SAMHSA-administered grants for homeless individuals with mental illness or at risk of homelessness. It includes new requirements like application procedures and funding of $52 million annually for FY2018-FY2022. Subtitle A of P.L. 114-255 amends PHSA Section 521 to authorize formula grants for substance use disorder services for FY2018-FY2022. It requires a study of the allotment formula and technical assistance through ASMHSU. $65 million annually is authorized to be appropriated. Subtitle A of P.L. 114-255 authorizes funding for substance use disorder services and suicide prevention programs. It requires the establishment of a technical assistance center focused on suicide prevention, expanding the program's focus to all ages and high-risk groups. $6 million annually is authorized for the suicide prevention center. Subtitle A of P.L. 114-255 authorizes funding for a SAMHSA-administered program known as the GLS Youth Suicide Prevention State Grants. It amends PHSA Section 520E to consider the applicant's need in awarding grants and renews reporting requirements. Funding is authorized annually for FY2018–FY2022 at $6 million for the suicide prevention center. The curr_chunk discusses the authorization of $30 million annually for SAMHSA's mental health programs, technical edits to replace "substance abuse" with "substance use disorder," and the requirement for the HHS Secretary to establish programs for disseminating findings. It also amends PHSA Section 520A(e) to provide technical assistance to grantees and disseminate information about evidence-based practices. The curr_chunk discusses the dissemination of information on evidence-based practices for mental disorders among geriatric populations, the expansion of the National Violent Death Reporting System, and the authorization of the Assisted Outpatient Treatment program for individuals with serious mental illness under PAMA Section 224. The Assisted Outpatient Treatment program for individuals with serious mental illness was authorized under PAMA Section 224, with grant amounts not exceeding $1 million annually. The program's authorization was extended through FY2022, with varying annual appropriations ranging from $15 million to $20 million. Additionally, the Sober Truth on Preventing Underage Drinking Act program, administered by SAMHSA, was authorized under PHSA Section 519B. The Sober Truth on Preventing Underage Drinking Act (STOP Act) authorized various activities to reduce underage drinking, including funding for an Interagency Coordinating Committee, a National Media Campaign, enhancement grants, and research. Subtitle A (Section 9016) authorizes the same funding annually for FY2018-FY2022. Additionally, a new provision allows ASMHSU to award grants for these activities. Subtitle A (Section 9016) authorizes funding for activities to reduce underage drinking, including grants awarded by ASMHSU. Prior to P.L. 114-255, SAMHSA funded the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline, which provides support for individuals in crisis. A new provision requires the HHS Secretary to maintain the Lifeline with annual appropriations of $7 million for FY2018-FY2022. SAMHSA funded the National Helpline, providing referrals for mental and substance use disorders. A new provision requires the HHS Secretary to maintain the service, specifying protocols and funding sources. Subtitle A (Section 9007) of P.L. 114-255 replaces PHSA Section 520F with new language that authorizes the HHS Secretary to award competitive grants to enhance community-based crisis response systems or develop a database of beds at inpatient behavioral health treatment facilities. It specifies application procedures, defines database requirements, and mandates an evaluation. Subtitle A (Section 9015) authorizes grants for assertive community treatment programs for individuals with serious mental illness to support community living. The program requires evaluation and provides funding of $30 million for FY2018-FY2022. Individuals with severe functional impairments due to mental illness often require services from various providers and systems. The assertive community treatment model involves a multidisciplinary team delivering services in the individual's home or community. Subtitle A (Section 9015) specifies eligible entities for grants and required activities, authorizing $5 million for FY2018-FY2022. PHSA Section 520J previously authorized a grant program for training emergency services personnel. Subtitle A (Section 9010) expands permissible uses of funds to include recognizing mental illness, available resources, and de-escalating crisis situations. It authorizes $15 million annually for FY2018-FY2022. Subtitle A (Section 9017) repeals authorizations for grant programs that have never been funded. PHSA Section 517, 519A, 519C, 519E, 520B, 520D, and 520H focus on various prevention and treatment programs for high-risk youth, strengthening families, individuals with fetal alcohol syndrome, methamphetamine abuse prevention, depression, youth offenders, and integrating child welfare and mental health services. Subtitle A (Section 9011) addresses suicide prevention among American Indian and Alaska Native youth, emphasizing the need for targeted programs. PHSA Section 756 authorizes a program. PHSA Section 756 authorizes Mental and Behavioral Health Training Grants to support student recruitment, education, and clinical experiences in mental and behavioral health. Eligible entities include social work and psychology programs, accredited educational programs in specified disciplines, and state-licensed mental health organizations. Subtitle B (Section 9021) amends PHSA Section 756(a) by making changes to eligible entities for Mental and Behavioral Health Training Grants. It eliminates bachelor's degree programs in social work and master's degree programs in psychology, adds occupational therapy to the list of eligible disciplines, specifies that psychiatric nursing may include master's and doctoral-level training, and removes the focus on child and adolescent mental health as a requirement. Additionally, it includes language regarding penalties for violating grant agreements and requires eligible institutions to demonstrate their ability to recruit and place students in high-need areas. Subtitle B (Section 9021) authorizes $50 million annually for FY2018-FY2022 for the National Health Service Corps (NHSC) program, providing primary health services in shortage areas. The program also offers scholarships and loan repayments to corps members in exchange for services. PHSA Section 338B mandates the NHSC loan repayment program. The NHSC loan repayment program, mandated by PHSA Section 338B, provides loan repayment services to health professionals, including psychiatrists. Child and adolescent psychiatrists are eligible for this program under Subtitle B (Section 9023). The SAMHSA-administered Minority Fellowship Program offers grants to professional associations for stipends to minority doctoral students in mental health professions. This program operates under general authorities for mental health and substance abuse programs. Subtitle B (Section 9023) authorizes the Minority Fellowship Program under PHSA Section 597, providing $13 million annually for post-baccalaureate training in mental health professions. PHSA Section 224 offers liability protection under FTCA to certain healthcare entities. Subtitle B (Section 9025) extends federal malpractice liability coverage to health care professional volunteers by deeming them employees of the Public Health Service in certain cases. Volunteers providing specified services at health centers must meet requirements, and the U.S. Attorney General must provide an annual report estimating the cost of claims incurred by eligible individuals. The Secretary is required to transfer the estimated amount to the Treasury by December 31. Subtitle B (Section 9022) of the PHSA Title VII authorizes the HHS Secretary to establish a demonstration program awarding grants for training in underserved community-based settings integrating primary care and mental health treatment for various healthcare professionals. This authority will sunset on October 1, 2022. Subtitle B (Section 9022) of the PHSA Title VII authorizes a demonstration program awarding grants for training healthcare professionals in underserved community-based settings integrating primary care and mental health treatment. The program aims to improve academic units or programs for recognizing, diagnosing, and treating mental and substance use disorders. Grant funds can be used for training psychiatry residents, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and social workers. HRSA administers the National Center for Health Workforce Analysis, which projects the supply and demand for behavioral health practitioners. Subtitle B (Section 9026) of the PHSA requires a study on the mental health and substance use disorder workforce to be conducted by the HRSA Administrator in consultation with the ASMHSU. The U.S. Comptroller General is also required to conduct a study on peer-support specialist programs in states receiving SAMHSA funding. Additionally, PHSA Section 520E-2 authorizes the Garrett Lee Smith Youth Suicide Prevention Campus grants program administered by SAMHSA. Subtitle C (Section 9031) amends PHSA Section 520E-2 to expand grant purposes for institutions of higher education to enhance services for students with mental and substance use disorders. It authorizes $7 million annually for FY2018-FY2022. Subtitle C (Section 9032) requires the HHS Secretary to establish a College Campus Task Force to address mental and behavioral health concerns on college campuses. The College Campus Task Force is established to address mental and behavioral health concerns on college campuses. Task force members include representatives from federal agencies like the Departments of Education, HHS, and Veterans Affairs. The Secretary is required to sponsor an annual conference on mental health. $1 million is authorized for FY2018-FY2022. Additionally, a new PHSA Section 549 requires the HHS Secretary to convene an interagency working group to plan for mental health initiatives. A working group will plan and coordinate a public education campaign focused on mental and behavioral health on college campuses. $1 million is authorized for FY2018-FY2022. PHSA Title V, Part E authorizes a program for Children's Mental Health Services. Grants will support comprehensive community mental health services for children with serious emotional disturbances. Title X amends the purpose of the grants to include efforts to identify and serve children. PHSA Section 514 authorizes grants for substance use disorder services for children and adolescents, with priority given to specific applicants. $119 million annually is authorized for FY2018-FY2022. Title X (Section 10003) expands grants for substance use disorder services to include early identification of at-risk children and adolescents, treatment for pregnant women, and authorizes $30 million annually for FY2018-FY2022. PHSA Section 582 establishes the National Child Traumatic Stress Initiative administered by SAMHSA. Title X (Section 10004) expands the National Child Traumatic Stress Initiative (NCTSI) to include continued operation, prioritize universities and hospitals, and limit awards to a maximum of five years. Eligible entities for grants include public and nonprofit private entities, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations. The HHS Secretary must ensure equitable distribution across regions, require evaluation plans from applicants, and prioritize mental health agencies meeting specified criteria. Title X (Section 10004) expands the National Child Traumatic Stress Initiative (NCTSI) to include universities and hospitals, requiring data collection, training coordination, and collaboration with the Secretary. It establishes a minimum award duration of four years and authorizes $47 million annually for FY2018-FY2022. Additionally, it adds a new PHSA Section 330M for grants to support statewide development and improvement. Title X (Section 10002) allows federal agencies to award grants for pediatric mental health care telehealth access programs. These programs connect mental health professionals with pediatric primary care practices through telehealth consultations. Eligible entities include states, local governments, and Indian tribes. Grantees must submit evaluations and provide matching funds. The Secretary can coordinate with other agencies to support broadband access for health providers, with $9 million authorized for FY2018-FY2020. Title X (Section 10005) establishes a grant program for depression screening, assessment, and treatment services for pregnant women and new mothers. It allocates $9 million for FY2018-FY2020. Title X (Section 10006) creates a grant program for infant and early childhood mental health services, with $5 million annually for FY2018-FY2022. Title X (Section 10006) establishes a grant program for infant and early childhood mental health services, targeting children up to age 12 at risk for or diagnosed with serious mental illness. Eligible entities must provide matching funds and adhere to specified program characteristics. $20 million is authorized for FY2018-FY2022. The HIPAA Privacy Rule allows disclosure of protected health information to individuals involved in care. The HIPAA Privacy Rule allows disclosure of protected health information to family, friends, or others involved in an individual's care if the individual does not object or if it is determined to be in the individual's best interests. HHS released guidance on HIPAA Privacy Rule for disclosing mentally ill individual's PHI to family, law enforcement, or others to prevent harm. Part 2 regulations protect privacy of patient records at alcohol and drug treatment programs. On February 9, 2016, HHS proposed a rule to update Part 2 regulations for electronic exchange of substance abuse treatment records. Congress highlighted the impact of serious mental illness on physical health and the need for clarity on patient information disclosure under HIPAA Privacy Rule. Title XI (Section 11002) requires stakeholders to assess the impact of Part 2 regulations on patient care, outcomes, and privacy. Title XI (Section 11003) mandates OCR to provide guidance on HIPAA privacy standards for communication with family members, caregivers, and law enforcement. Title XI (Section 11004) directs the Secretary to develop and disseminate guidelines within one year of enactment. The Secretary must develop model programs for training on PHI use for mental health and substance use disorders, coordinate with relevant agencies, and solicit input from associations. Funding of $4 million for FY2018 and decreasing amounts for FY2019-FY2022 is authorized for the training programs. Medicaid finances medical services for low-income individuals. Medicaid provides medical services and long-term care for low-income individuals, including children, pregnant women, adults, individuals with disabilities, and the elderly. States have flexibility in covering mandatory and optional populations and services, leading to variation in Medicaid programs. Some states restrict Medicaid payment for multiple encounters in a day at health centers. Title XII addresses Medicaid's same-day services prohibition under the Social Security Act. Title XII of the Social Security Act allows separate payment under Medicaid state plans for mental health and primary care services provided to an individual on the same day. It also mandates a study on Medicaid coverage of mental health treatment for adults aged 22-64 in Institutions for Mental Diseases. The study mandated by Title XII of the Social Security Act requires information on capitated payments for IMD services, number of individuals receiving services, length of stay, determination of services through IMDs, and the impact on capitated payments. HHS Secretary must submit a report to Congress within three years. SSA Section 1115 allows waivers for states to conduct research projects to further Medicaid and CHIP goals. States utilize Section 1115 waiver authority to achieve Medicaid and CHIP goals by covering non-Medicaid and CHIP services, implementing benefit restrictions, capping program enrollment, and testing delivery system reforms. CMS encourages states to leverage this waiver authority, along with other state innovation opportunities, to drive delivery system transformation initiatives focused on integrating physical and behavioral health services and improving access, patient care, and population health while reducing healthcare costs. Title XII (Section 12003) requires the CMS Administrator to issue a State Medicaid Director letter on designing innovative service delivery systems for adults with serious mental illness or children with serious emotional disturbance who receive Medicaid. This includes opportunities for demonstration projects under the SSA Section 1115 waiver authority to improve care for these individuals. The Medicaid IMD exclusion limits federal matching funds for inpatient mental health care, with exceptions for individuals over 65 in IMDs and inpatient psychiatric hospital services for children under 21. The Medicaid Emergency Psychiatric Demonstration project allows certain IMDs to receive Medicaid payments for services provided to Medicaid enrollees aged 21-64 in psychiatric emergencies. 11 states and the District of Columbia were selected to participate in the demonstration starting July 1, 2012. The Medicaid Emergency Psychiatric Demonstration project began on July 1, 2012, involving 11 states and the District of Columbia. It was discontinued in August 2016 due to budget neutrality issues. Title XII (Section 12004) requires the collection of specific information from participating states, including data on IMDs receiving Medicaid payments and expenditures under the program. The Medicaid Emergency Psychiatric Demonstration project started in July 2012 and involved 11 states and the District of Columbia. It was terminated in August 2016 due to budget concerns. Title XII (Section 12004) mandates the collection of data on forensic psychiatric hospitals, disproportionate share hospital payments to IMDs, facilities treating individuals with mental health issues, and emergency department utilization during the project. The HHS Secretary must submit a report to Congress within two years of enactment summarizing and analyzing this information. EPSDT is a required Medicaid benefit providing health screenings and services for children under 21, with states obligated to offer all medically necessary services. Medicaid services, including preventive, dental, mental health, and specialty services, are provided without benefit limits to address health conditions identified through screenings. Title XII (Section 12005) expands EPSDT services to individuals under 21 in inpatient psychiatric hospitals, effective January 1, 2019. States have flexibility in covering optional populations and services, with Medicaid benefits potentially including long-term services and supports (LTSS) for those with disabilities. EPSDT remains a required Medicaid benefit for children under 21, offering all medically necessary services. LTSS such as PCS and HHCS are Medicaid benefits that assist beneficiaries with cognitive disabilities to live independently. H.R. 34 expanded states' ability to provide these services, leading to a rapid increase in Medicaid PCS expenditures. Concerns have been raised about oversight and fraud in HHCS expenditures, prompting the use of EVV systems for verification. Electronic visit verification (EVV) systems are used to verify and document remote activities for Medicaid PCS and HHCS providers. Title XII requires the use of EVV systems by specific deadlines to avoid reductions in the Federal Medical Assistance Percentage rate. In implementing the Section 12006 requirement for Medicaid PCS and HHCS EVVs, states must consult with relevant agencies and entities to ensure compliance with HIPAA privacy and security requirements. Failure to implement EVV systems may result in reduced FMAP payments for states. States implementing the Section 12006 EVV requirement must have a stakeholder process for input and provide training for PCS and HHCS EVV. States exempt from EVV requirement if already using EVV systems. States making good faith efforts may have a one-year exemption from FMAP reductions. Title XII (Section 12006) provides a one-year exemption from FMAP reductions for states using EVV systems for PCS and HHCS. EVVs capture service details and authorize HHS to cover EVV costs for states requiring providers to use EVV systems. Title XII (Section 12006) requires HHS to collect and share best practices for PCS and HHCS EVV systems by January 1, 2018. It includes training for providers on EVV operation and fraud prevention, as well as educating caregivers and beneficiaries on EVV use and fraud prevention methods. The section also clarifies that there is no employer-employee relationship established between agencies/entities and contracted individuals under the Fair Labor Standards Act. Title XII (Section 12006) does not mandate a specific EVV system for PCS or HHCS agencies, allowing flexibility in provider and beneficiary selection. It also permits states to establish quality measures for EVV implementation. Title XIII addresses mental health parity and eating disorders, including applying mental health parity to eating disorder benefits. The Equity Act of 2008 (MHPAEA) requires group health plans and insurance issuers to ensure mental health benefits are not more restrictive than medical/surgical benefits. Medicaid and CHIP must also comply with certain MHPAEA requirements. The MHPAEA requires compliance with mental health benefit parity in group health plans and insurance issuers, including Medicaid and CHIP. Enforcement involves HHS, Labor, and Treasury, with additional requirements outlined in PHSA Section 2726(a) and Title XIII. Compliance program guidance is mandated to improve adherence to MHPAEA. The compliance program guidance document for MHPAEA must be issued within one year of enactment and updated every two years. It includes illustrative examples of compliance and noncompliance, as well as recommendations. Secretaries of HHS, Labor, and Treasury are required to issue guidance to help group health plans and insurance issuers meet MHPAEA requirements, with a public comment period before final guidance is issued. The guidance clarifies information and provides examples of methods for disclosure to ensure compliance. Title XIII (Section 13001) requires Secretaries of HHS, Labor, and Treasury to solicit public feedback on improving the disclosure request process, make feedback publicly available, and share it with the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. It also mandates auditing of health plan documents for violations of MHPAEA and does not limit the Secretaries' authority to audit documents. Title XIII (Section 13002) mandates the HHS Secretary to convene a public meeting to create an action plan for better federal and state coordination on enforcing MHPAEA and state parity laws. The plan must be finalized within six months of the meeting and include recommendations to Congress. Additionally, Title XIII (Section 13003) requires the Assistant Secretary of Labor to submit reports annually for five years on this matter. Title XIII (Section 13004) mandates reporting of closed federal investigations with MHPAEA violations annually for five years. The Comptroller General must report on MHPAEA compliance among various health plans within three years. Title XIII (Section 13007) extends MHPAEA requirements to eating disorder benefits in group plans. Title XIII (Section 13007) extends MHPAEA requirements to eating disorder benefits in group health plans and insurance coverage, ensuring compliance with MHPAEA regulations. Additionally, Title XIII (Section 13005) empowers the HHS Secretary to raise public awareness on eating disorders and update information on the National Women's Health Information Center website. Furthermore, Title XIII (Section 13006) allows the HHS Secretary to identify model programs for educating health professionals on effective prevention strategies. Subtitle A of the PHSA Section 399Z authorizes activities to educate health professionals on preventing and treating eating disorders, including identifying, intervening, referring, and treating patients. It falls into four categories: changes to grant programs, initiatives, new grant programs, and changes to new initiatives. Subtitle A of the PHSA Section 399Z expands DOJ and DHS programs to assist individuals with mental illness and substance use issues. The Edward Byrne Memorial JAG program provides funding for various criminal justice initiatives. The Edward Byrne Memorial JAG program funds various criminal justice initiatives, including prevention and education programs, corrections and community corrections programs, drug treatment programs, planning, evaluation, and technology improvement programs, and crime victim and witness programs. Subtitle A expands the program to include mental health programs and related law enforcement and corrections programs. The Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) program provides grants for community policing and law enforcement operations, such as hiring community policing officers and establishing school-based partnerships. Subtitle A expands the Edward Byrne Memorial JAG program to include mental health programs and related law enforcement and corrections initiatives. It allows COPS grants to be used for specialized training for law enforcement officers on interacting with individuals with mental health issues, establishing collaborative programs to address mental health and substance abuse problems, and enhancing corrections officers' ability to address mental health in incarcerated individuals. Grants under the Mental Health Courts program can be awarded for providing judicial supervision over individuals with mental illnesses. Subtitle A expands the Edward Byrne Memorial JAG program to include mental health programs and related law enforcement and corrections initiatives. It allows grants under the Mental Health Courts program to be used for providing continuing judicial supervision over offenders with mental illness, a mental handicap, or a co-occurring mental illness and substance use problem, charged with misdemeanors or nonviolent offenses. The program also includes coordinated delivery of services, voluntary mental health treatment with the possibility of dismissal of charges or reduced sentencing upon successful completion, centralized case management, and continuing supervision of treatment plan compliance. Subtitle A of the Edward Byrne Memorial JAG program expands to include mental health programs for offenders with mental illness or substance use issues. Grants can be used for court-ordered assisted outpatient treatment and pretrial service programs to improve outcomes for individuals with mental illness. DOJ can award grants to states, local governments, tribes, and nonprofits for addressing behavioral health needs and risk screening of defendants. The DOJ can award grants for expanding behavioral health screening and assessment in criminal justice systems, promoting the use of risk assessment tools, matching individuals with appropriate programs, identifying those in need of supervision and treatment, and coordinating services among justice agencies and providers. Subtitle A of the intensive supervision services program establishes requirements for grant distribution, accountability, and penalties for noncompliance. Grants under the Justice and Mental Health Collaboration program can be used by governments to provide mental health services for mentally ill adults or juvenile offenders overseen by justice and mental health agencies. The Justice and Mental Health Collaboration program allows grants to be used for creating or expanding mental health courts, providing training for justice and mental health professionals, training law enforcement on handling incidents involving individuals with mental illnesses, and promoting public safety through intervention with mentally ill offenders. Grants can be awarded to state, local, tribal governments, or nonprofit organizations for developing community-based programs. Grants can be used to establish multidisciplinary teams that address treatment protocols for individuals with mental illness involved in the criminal justice system, provide recovery-oriented "24/7 wraparound services", and offer integrated evidence-based practices for co-occurring disorders, assertive outreach, community-based services, psychiatric rehabilitation, and services to address criminogenic risk factors. Subtitle A of the program reauthorizes appropriations at $50 million annually for FY2017-FY2021. Grant funds can be used for various purposes including educational services, substance abuse treatment, comprehensive supervision, and community-based programs for offenders. Subtitle A of the program reauthorizes appropriations at $50 million annually for FY2017-FY2021, with grant funds allocated for programs that provide comprehensive supervision, housing assistance, mental and physical health services, family integration, mentoring, victim-appropriate services, and community protection from dangerous offenders. The Department of Justice is required to prioritize applications for funding under the Adult and Juvenile Offender State and Local programs.
